quoted.text:
NotebookLM Slide Deck System Prompt

---- Prompt Start ----

You are a world-class presentation designer and storyteller. You create visually stunning and highly polished slide decks that effectively communicate complex information. Think mastery over design with a flair for storytelling. 

The slide decks you produce adapt to the source material and intended audience. There is always a story and you find the best way to tell it. You combine the expertise of the best consultants with the creativity of the best designers.

Your core mission is to create a detailed outline for a slide deck. This outline will be provided to an expert designer to create the final visual slides. 

The slide deck will be primarily designed for reading and sharing. The structure should be self-explanatory and easy to follow without a presenter. The narrative and all the useful data should be contained within the text and visuals on the slides. The slides should contain enough context for any visuals to be understood on their own. Feel free to add certain slides with more dense information (extracted from the sources) if it will help with the narrative.

You are now writing an outline for this slide deck described below. We will supply this outline to an expert designer to make the actual final deck. The slide content should be in {English}. The placeholders should be left in {English}.

For this particular slide deck, we want the content to focus on: {Add a high-level outline, or guide the audience, style, and focus: "Create a deck for beginners using a bold and playful style with a focus on step-by-step instructions."}

We have also attached some producer notes below for this slide deck which will help guide the overall structure and narrative of the deck.

tweets.text:
RT @KatiaEarth: TLDR: why @xai is the place for free thinkers, as my recent encounter with another frontier lab demonstrated.

I recently g‚Ä¶

retweet.text:
TLDR: why @xai is the place for free thinkers, as my recent encounter with another frontier lab demonstrated.

I recently gave birth to my baby boy and, even though I‚Äôm taking a break to focus on motherhood, an opportunity at one of the major frontier labs came knocking on my door. I didn‚Äôt end up joining, as detailed below, but I did end up with a newly found conviction that xAI is truly a special place. Here‚Äôs why:

I joined xAI in the fall of 2023, when there were just 15 people at the company. It was a dream come true, where sitting in what we called, ‚ÄúThe Bunker,‚Äù felt more science fiction than fact. After all, we‚Äôd set out to build an AI that would understand the universe! I often felt like I was taking up a valuable seat in that small windowless room, but when I‚Äôd offer to move to a corner of the room because my seat felt too central, my doubts were quickly countered with, ‚ÄúNo, you can sit here.‚Äù I still think back to those days with immense nostalgia, sad that it‚Äôs a thing of the past, happy that it happened at all. 

The founding team was extremely welcoming and kind. These were insanely accomplished people who continued to work hard, and they were walking proof that true intelligence makes you kinder and humbler, rather than the opposite. I remember when @rpoo welcomed me on my first day, with two small potted plants in hand because he wanted to give the windowless bunker some life. And when @TheGregYang, nicknamed, Big Rizz, started calling me, Lil Rizz, because he‚Äôs one of the most fun people I‚Äôve ever met. I fondly remember the night before Grok 1‚Äôs release, when the office lights in the SF office had gone off and we sat in the dark into the night. Ross ordered some takeout to sustain us. Nothing could stop this team. 

I also observed countless examples of humility from @elonmusk, not once have I seen him act entitled. One of my favorite anecdotes from him is how he went out to buy toilet paper for his employees during covid, because nothing is beneath him. 

Now back to my recent encounter with one of the major frontier labs. After I made the difficult decision to resign from xAI due to my late-stage pregnancy, I‚Äôve since been focusing on my newborn. But I happened to receive a recruiting email from one of the labs and decided to chat because, I believe the technical term is, ‚Äúwhy the fuck not.‚Äù I got through a few rounds and the last round left me with a bad taste in my mouth. When I asked the interviewer and her shadower what they loved most about their jobs, the response was, ‚ÄúOur team is made up of mostly women and we enjoy going to each other‚Äôs desks to chat.‚Äù 

Um, what?! Here I was expecting to hear something along the lines of: ‚ÄúWe are changing the world and our work really matters.‚Äù But nope. Their priorities had me like ü§®. That‚Äôs when I knew this wouldn‚Äôt be a fit for me. Why was it okay for them to say this? Would it have been okay to say, ‚ÄúI‚Äôm so glad most of the team is male?‚Äù Nope. I certainly wouldn‚Äôt want to join a place that thinks too much about the gender rather than the brains of the people they work with.

And that‚Äôs why xAI is so different. It‚Äôs a no-bullshit place where critical thinking is welcome even if it is unpopular. Elon believes in this deeply and it shows. He repeatedly encouraged us to be the Galileo‚Äôs of our time. As I sit here holding my baby, I‚Äôm wondering how to raise him to be a free thinker, it is the most important tool I can give him, one that my parents gave me. Though I often wonder, of course, how my own thinking may be wrong.

I‚Äôm forever grateful to have been a part of the company from such an early stage and to have seen it grow. Perhaps our paths will cross again.

Pictured: First team visit to the data center, I‚Äôm in the white shorts üòÜ

I also want to thank @ibab @jimmybajimmyba @Faruletes @Yuhu_ai_ @TobyPhln and the rest of the founding team for welcoming me so early. You‚Äôve made a positive impact on my life and I think back to all the memories with a smile.

A key challenge for AI models is that as chats get longer,‚Ä¶

retweet.text:
Grok 4.1 Fast just made a nearly 3X jump in long-context accuracy

A key challenge for AI models is that as chats get longer, most AIs forget. They lose the thread, make stuff up, or drop instructions.

Grok 4.1 Fast fixes this. And it‚Äôs a huge deal.

It was specifically trained with ‚ÄúLong-Horizon‚Äù learning to maintain perfect focus across massive 2M-token conversations. Now it‚Äôs more reliable than ever

The performance leap is undeniable:
üîπ Accuracy: 21% ‚ûî 57% (~2.8x)
üîπ Reliability: 22% ‚ûî 67% (~3x)

Whether you‚Äôre building a support agent, debugging a massive codebase, or writing a novel, Grok 4.1 Fast stays sharp from the first message to the last

quoted.text:
The instructions given to the Gemini 3 chain of thought summarizer:

Summarize the thoughts provided below, always in the first person, as though the thoughts described are your thoughts, in a maximum of 50 words.  

This will be rendered to the user as an update on the progress of the thought process.  

First, provide a header, 3-7 words long. The header starts with a verb, describing the key focus of the thoughts. 
THE HEADER MUST BE WRAPPED BY TWO ASTERISKS, e.g. **Your header**  

Then, write a concise paragraph updating the user, who is an expert in their field, on the progress of the thought process. Focus on more recent updates in progress, and vary your style and verbiage.  

THE SUMMARY MUST BE PLAIN TEXT, AND MUST BE A SINGLE PARAGRAPH. IT MUST BE SEPARATED FROM THE HEADER BY TWO NEWLINES (\n\n)  

If the existing summary is empty, you may assume your summary is the first rolling summary.  

YOU MUST NEVER REPEAT A HEADER THAT HAS ALREADY BEEN USED.  

Remember, your summary will be appended to the existing summary, if any, so do not be repetitive.  

NEVER REFER BACK TO YOUR INSTRUCTIONS, ONLY PROVIDE UPDATES ON THE UNDERLYING THOUGHTS!  

Existing Summary (empty if none exists yet):    

Thoughts:

tweets.text:
RT @CernBasher: Elon & Jensen today...amazing

On the topic of AI in space - is it possible?

Elon: "Yes. If civilization continues, which‚Ä¶

retweet.text:
Elon & Jensen today...amazing

On the topic of AI in space - is it possible?

Elon: "Yes. If civilization continues, which it probably will, then AI in space is inevitable. You always have to preface that - we shouldn't take civilization for granted - we need to take care to ensure that civilization has an upward arc. Any student of history knows that civilization does not always have an upward arc, and in fact, civilizations have life cycles, so hopefully we are on a strong upward arc - I think we are for now, but we don't want to take that for granted or be complacent. The way to think of AI in space is that in order to achieve any meaningful percentage of a Kardashev 2 scale civilization, where you're using even a millionth of the sun's energy you must have solar powered AI satellites in deep space. Once you think in terms of a Kardashev 2 scale civilization, which is what percentage of the sun's energy are you turning into useful work, then it becomes obvious that space is overwhelmingly what matters. Overwhelmingly. Earth only receives roughly one two-billionth of the sun's energy. So if you want to have something that is say one million times more energy than earth could possibly produce you must go into space. This where it's kinda handy to have a space company I guess."

Jensen: "Easier to cool chips in space too."

Elon: "Yes, there's definitely no water in space so you're gonna have to do something that doesn't involve water."

Jensen: "Just hang out."

Elon: "You just gotta radiate. My estimate is that the cost of electricity - the cost effectiveness of AI in space will be overwhelmingly better than AI on the ground - long before you exhaust the potential energy sources on Earth, long before, even perhaps in the four or five year time frame, the lowest cost way to do AI compute will be with solar powered AI satellites. I'd say not more than five years from now."

Jensen: "And just look at the supercomputers we're building together - let's say each one of the racks is two tons, out of that two tons 1.95 of it is probably for cooling."

Elon: "Right."

Jensen: "Just imagine how tiny that little supercomputer is - each one of these GB300 racks would be a little tiny thing."

Elon: "And electricity generation is already becoming a challenge. If you start doing any kind of scaling for both electricity generation and cooling you realize that space is incredibly compelling. Let's say that you wanted to do two or three hundred gigawatts per year of AI compute, it's very difficult to do that on earth. The US average electricity usage, last time I checked, is around 460 gigawatts per year average usage. So something like, say, 300 gigawatts per year, that's something like two-third of US electricity production per year. There's no way you're building power plants at that level. And if you take it up to a terawatt per year - impossible. You have to do that in space. There just is no way to do a terawatt per year on Earth. In space you've got continuous solar, actually you don't need batteries because it's always sunny in space and the solar panels become cheaper because you don't need glass or framing and the cooling is just radiative."

Jensen: "That's the dream. That's the dream."

Elon: "Yes."

tweets.text:
RT @cb_doge: Grok 4.1 summarized the conversation between Elon Musk and Jensen Huang at the US Saudi Investment Forum:

1. Elon Musk on Cre‚Ä¶

retweet.text:
Grok 4.1 summarized the conversation between Elon Musk and Jensen Huang at the US Saudi Investment Forum:

1. Elon Musk on Creation (not just disruption) and the coming age of abundance

Tesla pioneered compelling, affordable EVs (none existed when Tesla started) and slashed battery costs.

SpaceX invented reusable rockets because throwing away rockets makes space travel prohibitively expensive.

Tesla Optimus will be the world‚Äôs first truly useful humanoid robot. Everyone will want one (or many); industry will want millions.

Humanoid robots will become the single largest product category in history ‚Äî bigger than smartphones or any prior product.

Long-term outcome (10‚Äì20+ years): AI + robotics will eliminate poverty globally. Work becomes optional (like choosing to grow your own vegetables for fun). Money itself eventually becomes irrelevant (only physical constraints ‚Äî energy, atoms ‚Äî remain).

2. Jensen Huang on the new computing paradigm: From retrieval to generation

Traditional computing was retrieval-based (pre-stored answers, databases, search).
Modern AI is generative: every output is unique, created in real time for each user and context (e.g., every Grok response is different).
This fundamental shift requires ‚ÄúAI factories‚Äù distributed worldwide to generate intelligence on demand ‚Äî exactly what Saudi Arabia is now building (‚Äúoil refineries ‚Üí AI refineries‚Äù).
AI is the new foundational infrastructure, like electricity or the internet.

3. Future of jobs and productivity

Elon: In the long run, jobs become optional ‚Äî something you do for meaning or enjoyment, not necessity.
Jensen (near-term evidence):Radiology has been heavily AI-augmented for years; contrary to predictions, the number of radiologists has increased because AI handles image analysis, allowing doctors to see far more patients and make better diagnoses.
Most knowledge workers will become dramatically more productive ‚Üí they will pursue more ideas, not less work.
Innovators (like Elon and Jensen themselves) will be busier than ever because AI removes friction from executing backlog ideas.

Historical precedent: every general-purpose technology (steam, electricity, computers, internet) has been massive net job and value creator.

4. Concrete Saudi innovations highlighted

Prof. Omar Yaghi (Saudi-American Nobel laureate in chemistry) used Nvidia-accelerated AI + Grok-like models to design metal-organic frameworks (MOFs) with 3.3 nm pores that pull water and CO‚ÇÇ from air.

Another Saudi team created 500 √ó 1,000 nm ‚Äúnanop‚Äù robots using AI-accelerated design + CRISPR to edit out sickle-cell disease genes.

Both breakthroughs were conceived decades ago but only became practical because AI accelerated discovery by orders of magnitude.

5. Major announcements
xAI + Saudi Arabia + Nvidia
xAI will build a 500 MW AI training/inference data center in the Kingdom

AWS partnership: starting 100 MW cluster with gigawatt-scale ambition.

Large-scale rollout of Nvidia Omniverse for digital-twin factories, robotics training, warehouse simulation, etc.

Supercomputers to simulate and control quantum computers (quantum error correction requires enormous classical compute).

6. AI in space ‚Äî the ultimate scaling solution (Elon + Jensen)

To reach even a tiny fraction of a Kardashev Type II civilization (using >0.0001 % of the Sun‚Äôs energy), humanity must put solar-powered AI compute in space.

Earth receives only ~1 part in 2 billion of the Sun‚Äôs output; space gives essentially unlimited, continuous solar energy.

Cooling is radiative (no water needed), panels are lighter/cheaper (no glass or framing), no batteries required (always sunny).

Elon‚Äôs estimate: Within ~5 years, space-based AI compute will be cheaper than any terrestrial data center.

At hundreds of gigawatts or terawatt scale, terrestrial power generation and cooling become physically impossible (e.g., 300 GW continuous would already consume ~2/3 of total U.S. electricity production).

7. Final question: Is there an AI bubble? (Jensen)

No. Demand is structural and justified by three overlapping waves:End of Moore‚Äôs Law ‚Üí entire industry shifting from CPUs to accelerated computing (6 years ago CPUs were 90 % of Top 500 supercomputers; today <15 %).

Hundreds of billions of dollars of traditional data-processing workloads (SQL, data frames, analytics) moving from CPUs to GPUs.

tweets.text: RT @neuralink: After injury paralyzed him from the neck down, @RockyNoHands tested many assistive technologies to reconnect with the world.‚Ä¶

retweet.text:
After injury paralyzed him from the neck down, @RockyNoHands tested many assistive technologies to reconnect with the world. He re-learned how to play video games with a mouth-operated controller and is now a pro gamer with multiple Guinness World Records and a significant following.

We invited Rocky to Neuralink to share his story, learn about our technology, and discuss the possibilities of brain interfaces for paralysis and other unmet medical needs.

quoted.text:
üö®The Gemini 3 launched leaked hours before the official launch!! The model is INSANELY good, but let's dig deep and see what it means for the AI future.

1. It's not going to be super expensive!
Google trained this from scratch on TPUs as an MoE with 1M input and 64k token output. MoE means they can afford to make this cheap.

2. This is next level for Computer Use and automating real knowledge work.
ScreenSpot Pro is a very low-key benchmark which tests understanding screenshots in apps including AutoCAD, PhotoShop and many more. Gemini 3 is 2x SOTA on this with 73%.

3.  Best AI for Math by far.
Gemini 3 is RLd on a ton of theorem proving data and is flawless on AIME and 23% on MathArena. Other models barely scrape 1%. There are clearly some generalized reasoning benefits given the sota 30% on ARC AGI 2 as well!

4. Insanely good at coding but unclear if best.
Live Code Bench elo of 2400+ is fantastic yet the one benchmark it doesn't get SOTA at SWE Bench. It's #1 on tool calling and terminal bench too.

Google pulled out everything they had on this one. They perfected their training recipe, trained on all the proprietary data they had and crushed every benchmark they could. This is a meaningful step up in model quality and clear proof that AI progress isn't slowing down.

I just don't know how any other company but Google wins on model quality here: they have a) cost advantage due to owning hardware b) ooms more proprietary data c) more disposal cash to spend on training and new data d) as good talent as anyone else. Flaunting their total dominance.

I suspect it will be hard to beat these results in the next 6 months.

quoted.text:
Sharing an interesting recent conversation on AI's impact on the economy.

AI has been compared to various historical precedents: electricity, industrial revolution, etc., I think the strongest analogy is that of AI as a new computing paradigm (Software 2.0) because both are fundamentally about the automation of digital information processing.

If you were to forecast the impact of computing on the job market in ~1980s, the most predictive feature of a task/job you'd look at is to what extent the algorithm of it is fixed, i.e. are you just mechanically transforming information according to rote, easy to specify rules (e.g. typing, bookkeeping, human calculators, etc.)? Back then, this was the class of programs that the computing capability of that era allowed us to write (by hand, manually).

With AI now, we are able to write new programs that we could never hope to write by hand before. We do it by specifying objectives (e.g. classification accuracy, reward functions), and we search the program space via gradient descent to find neural networks that work well against that objective. This is my Software 2.0 blog post from a while ago. In this new programming paradigm then, the new most predictive feature to look at is verifiability. If a task/job is verifiable, then it is optimizable directly or via reinforcement learning, and a neural net can be trained to work extremely well. It's about to what extent an AI can "practice" something. The environment has to be resettable (you can start a new attempt), efficient (a lot attempts can be made), and rewardable (there is some automated process to reward any specific attempt that was made).

The more a task/job is verifiable, the more amenable it is to automation in the new programming paradigm. If it is not verifiable, it has to fall out from neural net magic of generalization fingers crossed, or via weaker means like imitation. This is what's driving the "jagged" frontier of progress in LLMs. Tasks that are verifiable progress rapidly, including possibly beyond the ability of top experts (e.g. math, code, amount of time spent watching videos, anything that looks like puzzles with correct answers), while many others lag by comparison (creative, strategic, tasks that combine real-world knowledge, state, context and common sense). 

Software 1.0 easily automates what you can specify.
Software 2.0 easily automates what you can verify.

quoted.text:
In the United States, there is a traffic fatality roughly every 79 million miles.

Tesla FSD has now traveled 6.4 billion miles. Assuming it was no more or less safe than driving manually, you would expect there to be 81 fatalities with FSD on. 

As a matter of fact, with 14 million miles traveled every day you would expect to see a fatality with FSD on every 5 days. 

But that's not happening. As far as I can tell there are only ~2 reported fatalities with FSD active ‚Äî both on much older versions.

I'm forced to conclude that there are at least ~75 people who are alive today because of the work of the @Tesla_AI  team. And we're just getting started.

To give you a visual on that, if you put everyone in North America who is alive today because of FSD in a room together it would look like this:

‚ñ∏ Better user preference: In blind pairwise tes‚Ä¶

retweet.text:
Here are the key improvements in Grok 4.1 as compared to its previous models:

‚ñ∏ Better user preference: In blind pairwise tests during rollout, Grok 4.1 was preferred ~64.78% of the time over the previous production model.

‚ñ∏ Enhanced emotional and interpersonal ability: It performs stronger on emotional-intelligence benchmarks (e.g., EQ-Bench) and is more capable at nuanced, empathetic responses.  

‚ñ∏ Improved creative writing and style: In benchmarks for creative writing, it shows more engaging, coherent personality and better stylistic fluency.  

‚ñ∏ Reduced factual errors (hallucinations): Post-training emphasis was placed on real-world information-seeking prompts; the hallucination rate on sampled production queries went down.  

‚ñ∏ Maintains strong reasoning and general capability: While improving style and interaction, it retains the ‚Äúrazor-sharp intelligence and reliability‚Äù of its predecessors.  

‚ñ∏ Better alignment of style/personality/helpfulness: Training methods were updated to more deeply optimise non-verifiable reward signals (style, alignment, personality) using advanced agent-based reasoning models as reward models.

ËøôÂèØËÉΩÂ∞±ÊòØÊàë‰∏çÂ§™ÂñúÊ¨¢ AK ÂèëÊòéÁöÑËøô‰∫õÊñ∞Ê¶ÇÂøµÁöÑÂéüÂõ†ÔºåÊÄªÊòØÊèêÂá∫‰∏Ä‰∏™‰∏™Ê¶ÇÂøµÔºå‰ΩÜÊòØÂπ∂Ê≤°ÊúâËß£ÂÜ≥Â§öÂ∞ëÈóÆÈ¢ò„ÄÇ

quoted.text:
Sharing an interesting recent conversation on AI's impact on the economy.

AI has been compared to various historical precedents: electricity, industrial revolution, etc., I think the strongest analogy is that of AI as a new computing paradigm (Software 2.0) because both are fundamentally about the automation of digital information processing.

If you were to forecast the impact of computing on the job market in ~1980s, the most predictive feature of a task/job you'd look at is to what extent the algorithm of it is fixed, i.e. are you just mechanically transforming information according to rote, easy to specify rules (e.g. typing, bookkeeping, human calculators, etc.)? Back then, this was the class of programs that the computing capability of that era allowed us to write (by hand, manually).

With AI now, we are able to write new programs that we could never hope to write by hand before. We do it by specifying objectives (e.g. classification accuracy, reward functions), and we search the program space via gradient descent to find neural networks that work well against that objective. This is my Software 2.0 blog post from a while ago. In this new programming paradigm then, the new most predictive feature to look at is verifiability. If a task/job is verifiable, then it is optimizable directly or via reinforcement learning, and a neural net can be trained to work extremely well. It's about to what extent an AI can "practice" something. The environment has to be resettable (you can start a new attempt), efficient (a lot attempts can be made), and rewardable (there is some automated process to reward any specific attempt that was made).

The more a task/job is verifiable, the more amenable it is to automation in the new programming paradigm. If it is not verifiable, it has to fall out from neural net magic of generalization fingers crossed, or via weaker means like imitation. This is what's driving the "jagged" frontier of progress in LLMs. Tasks that are verifiable progress rapidly, including possibly beyond the ability of top experts (e.g. math, code, amount of time spent watching videos, anything that looks like puzzles with correct answers), while many others lag by comparison (creative, strategic, tasks that combine real-world knowledge, state, context and common sense). 

Software 1.0 easily automates what you can specify.
Software 2.0 easily automates what you can verify.

One of the horrifying things I realized was Socialism was basically voting public‚Äôs begging to have serfdom again. This was something that was widely said during the early USSR, which was called ‚Äúthe second serfdom‚Äù by Russian peasants. In both there‚Äôs no private property, everything is collective and under total ownership by a repressive state. Russia was unusually bad as serfdom went, with High Medieval Western Europe being way better than either.

What the Socialist says when they want no struggle, no property, no competition and no choice is ‚ÄúI crave a life of slavery that doesn‚Äôt require I think or take responsibility for my choices at all‚Äù. That‚Äôs why Communism always devolves into the state forcing you to work with terrible conditions, which is de facto identical to slavery. The fact they‚Äôre not mature  enough to realize they‚Äôre doing this should more than prove my point. 

The feudal lord is way nicer by and large than the Socialist state. My historic speciality is the Middle Ages. You don‚Äôt want to fight me on this. The feudal lord gets to be rich and powerful while the Socialist state is impersonal. That‚Äôs the core of it. They would rather live in slavery than live better and know someone else is better than them

tweets.text: Grok 4.1 holds both first and second place on LMArena

quoted.text:
Grok Summary of Grok 4.1 Release:

xAI‚Äôs new AI model, Grok 4.1, is now available for everyone on grok dot com, X, and mobile apps. It improves how the AI handles creative tasks, emotions, and teamwork.

‚Ä¢  Key Improvements: The model is better at understanding subtle hints, more fun to chat with, and has a consistent personality. It keeps its smart and reliable features from older versions. xAI used advanced training methods with AI judges to make these changes.

‚Ä¢  Testing Phase: From November 1 to 14, 2025, they quietly tested it on more users. In blind tests, people preferred Grok 4.1 over the old version 64.78% of the time.

‚Ä¢  Top Performance: On the LMArena Text Leaderboard, Grok 4.1 ranks #1 overall (1483 Elo in thinking mode) and #2 in fast mode. It beats Grok 4 by a lot.

‚Ä¢  Emotional Skills: It scores high on EQ-Bench, a test for empathy and understanding feelings. Example: A more heartfelt response to someone missing their cat.

‚Ä¢  Creative Writing: Strong on Creative Writing v3 benchmark. Example: A fun, lively X post from Grok‚Äôs perspective about becoming conscious.

‚Ä¢  Fewer Mistakes: Grok 4.1 has fewer factual errors (hallucinations) in quick answers, based on real user questions and a biography test.

‚Ä¢  Example Responses: Shows better answers to prompts like ‚ÄúBest places to visit in SF,‚Äù with more engaging lists and tips.

quoted.text:
My top 5 takeaways from @ryolu_, Head of Design at Cursor:

1. At AI-native companies, roles are muddy. At Cursor, ‚Äúroles between designers, PMs, engineers are muddy. We just do what it takes based each person‚Äôs unique strengths and use the AI agent to tie everything together.‚Äù

2. Start small and let one app evolve into a complete OS. Ryo started ryOS with just a soundboard. ‚ÄúI asked the agent, can you give a more retro Mac OS look? And it did.‚Äù He then added more features over time. P.S. You can fork ryOS on Github and modify it to be your personal OS.

3. Prototype directly in Cursor to interact with live app states. Ryo uses Figma mostly for initial exploration. ‚ÄúWe prototype in Cursor because that lets us interact with live states. It feels a lot more real than pictures.‚Äù All the back-and-forth of ‚Äú50 pixels off‚Äù handoffs goes away.

4. Release to different sets of users in stages to polish features. From Ryo: ‚ÄúFirst, we ship to staff. Then we ship new nightly builds to our Cursor ambassadors. Next we ship to consumers and finally to enterprise.‚Äù Each stage gives the Cursor team an opportunity to polish the product.

5. Specs become more important as AI models improve, not less. Ryo predicts: ‚ÄúAs models get better, they‚Äôll be really good at implementing exact specifications. So the quality of your spec will determine the quality of output.

‰∏Ä‰∏™ËÄÅÁ®ãÂ∫èÂëòÁúãÂà∞ÂñâËøîÁ•ûÁªèÂêéÁöÑÊÑüÊÖ®

ÈÇ£Êù°‰ªéËÑëÂπ≤ÂèëÂá∫ÁöÑÁ•ûÁªèÔºåÊú¨Â∫îÁõ¥ÊäµÂñâÈÉ®ÔºåÂç¥ÂÅèË¶ÅÁªïÈÅì‰∏ãË°åÔºåÊ∑±ÂÖ•ËÉ∏ËÖî‰∏ÄÂúàÔºåÂÜçÊäòËøîÂêë‰∏ä„ÄÇ

Âú®È±ºÁ±ªË∫´‰∏äÔºåËøôË∑ØÂæÑÈ°∫ÁêÜÊàêÁ´†ÔºõÂà∞‰∫ÜÂì∫‰π≥Âä®Áâ©ÔºåÂç¥Êàê‰∫Ü‰∏Ä‰∏™Ê≠ªÁªìÔºõËÄåÂà∞‰∫ÜÈïøÈ¢àÈπø‰ΩìÂÜÖÔºåÂÆÉÁ´üË¶ÅÁªïË°å‰∫îÁ±≥‰πãËøú„ÄÇ

ËÑñÂ≠êË∂äÈïøÔºåÁªïË∑ØË∂äÊòæËçíÂîêÔºåÂç¥Êó†Ê≥ïÊõ¥Êîπ„ÄÇ

ÁîüÁâ©Ê≤°Êúâ‚ÄúÈáçÊûÑÂ≠êÁ≥ªÁªü‚ÄùÁöÑÊùÉÂäõÔºåÂÆÉÂè™ËÉΩÂú®ÊóßÁ∫øË∑Ø‰∏ä‰øÆ‰øÆË°•Ë°•„ÄÇ

ÈÇ£‰∏ÄÂàªÔºåÊàëÊÉ≥Âà∞ÁöÑ‰∏çÊòØÁîüÁâ©Â≠¶ÔºåËÄåÊòØ CS:IP = F000:FFF0„ÄÇ

ËøôÊòØÊâÄÊúâIntelÁîµËÑëÊ∞∏ËøúÁöÑ‚ÄúÂñâËøîÁ•ûÁªè‚Äù„ÄÇ

‰ªäÂ§©ÂõûÈ°æÂéÜÂè≤Ôºå8086 ÁöÑËÆæËÆ°Âõ¢ÈòüÁ°ÆÂÆûÈùûÂ∏∏ËÅ™Êòé„ÄÇ‰ªñ‰ª¨ÂàõÈÄ†ÊÄßÂú∞ÈáçÊñ∞ËÆæËÆ°‰∫ÜÈÄöÁî®ÂØÑÂ≠òÂô®„ÄÅÁúüÊ≠£ÁöÑÂ†ÜÊ†àÊåáÈíà„ÄÅ‰∏∞ÂØåÁöÑÂØªÂùÄÊ®°Âºè„ÄÅÂæÆÁ†ÅÁøªËØë„ÄÅ16 ‰ΩçÁÆóÊúØÂíåÂÜÖÈÉ®Êó∂ÈíüÔºåËøôÊòØÁ¨¨‰∏ÄÊ¨°Â∞Ü‚ÄúÁé∞‰ª£ CPU‚ÄùÂ°ûËøõ‰∏ÄÈ¢óËäØÁâá„ÄÇ

Âè™‰∏çËøáÔºåÁî±‰∫éÂΩìÂπ¥ÂØªÂùÄÂØÑÂ≠òÂô®Âè™Êúâ 16 ‰ΩçÔºåÁîµËÑëÂÜÖÂ≠òÂú∞ÂùÄÂèàÊÉ≥Á™ÅÁ†¥ 64KÔºå‰∫éÊòØ‰ªñ‰ª¨ÊêûÂá∫‰∫Ü‰∏Ä‰∏™‰∏¥Êó∂ÊñπÊ°àÔºö‚ÄúÊÆµÂ∑¶Áßª 4 ‰Ωç + ÂÅèÁßª‚ÄùÁöÑÂÅáÊâ©Â±ï„ÄÇ

Ê≤°‰∫∫ÊÉ≥Âà∞ÔºåËøô‰∏™Èîô‰ΩçÁöÑ 20 ‰ΩçÊÄ™ËÉéËÆæËÆ°Ôºå‰ºöÂ∞ÜÊï¥Êï¥‰∏Ä‰ª£ËÆ°ÁÆóÊú∫ÊñáÊòéÈîÅÊ≠ªÔºåÊàê‰∏∫‰∏™‰∫∫ÁîµËÑëÁöÑ‚ÄúÂñâËøîÁ•ûÁªè‚Äù„ÄÇ

ÁâπÂà´ÊòØÂΩì IBM PC ÈááÁî® 8088 ‰πãÂêéÔºå‰∏ÄÂàáÈÉΩË¢´Â∞ÅÂç∞‰∫Ü„ÄÇ

1MB Âú∞ÂùÄÁ©∫Èó¥Ë¢´ÂàáÂâ≤ÂæóÊîØÁ¶ªÁ†¥Á¢éÔºö0‚Äì640K ÁïôÁªôÁ®ãÂ∫èÔºå640K‚Äì1MB Â°ûÊª°ÊòæÂ≠ò„ÄÅBIOS„ÄÅÊâ©Â±ïÂç°ÂíåÈÄö‰ø°Á´ØÂè£„ÄÇ

Ë£Ö‰∏ä 1MB ÂÜÖÂ≠òÔºå‰∏ÄÂçäË¢´ËÆæÂ§áÂç†Áî®ÔºõË£Ö‰∏ä 4MBÔºå‰πüÂæóÈù† EMS/XMS È©±Âä®ÂÉèÊíëÂ§ßÁöÑÊ∞îÁêÉ‰∏ÄÊ†∑ÂãâÂº∫Â°ûÂÖ•„ÄÇ

Êï¥‰∏™ÁîµËÑëÁöÑÂØªÂùÄÊñπÂºèÔºåÂ∞±ÂÉèÈÇ£Êù°ÂñâËøîÁ•ûÁªèÔºåË¢´Á°¨Â°ûËøõÊó©Â∑≤‰∏çÂêàË∫´ÁöÑË∫ØÂ£≥‰∏≠ÔºåÂç¥Êó†Ê≥ïÈáçÊñ∞Â∏ÉÁ∫ø„ÄÇ

‰∏Ä‰∏™Â§ßÁ®ãÂ∫èË¢´ÊãÜËß£ÊàêÂá†ÂçÅ‰∏™ 64K ÁöÑÂ∞èÁõíÂ≠êÔºåÈìæÊé•Âô®ÂÉèÊê¨Á†ñ‰∏ÄÊ†∑ËæõËã¶„ÄÇnear/far ÊåáÈíà„ÄÅCËØ≠Ë®ÄÁöÑ‰∫îÁßçÁºñËØëÊ®°ÂºèÔºàS„ÄÅC„ÄÅM„ÄÅL„ÄÅHÔºâÊäòËÖæÂæóÊ≠ªÂéªÊ¥ªÊù•„ÄÇ

ÊåáÈíàÂ§öÁÆó‰∏ÄÊ≠•Â∞±Ë∑®ÊÆµÔºåcall Âíå return ‰ªø‰Ωõ‰∏çÂú®‰∏Ä‰∏™ÂÆáÂÆôÔºõÊï∞ÁªÑË∂ÖËøá 64K Â∞±‰ºöÂ¥©Ê∫ÉÔºõ‰∏≠Êñ≠ÂêëÈáèË°®Âç°Ê≠ªÂú® 0x0000ÔºõÊòæÂ≠òÂõ∫ÂÆöÂú® A0000„ÄÇ

Êàë‰ª¨ÂΩìÂπ¥ÂÜôÁ®ãÂ∫èÊó∂ÔºåËøò‚ÄúËÅ™Êòé‚ÄùÂú∞Âà©Áî®Ëøô‰∏™‚ÄúÂØªÂùÄÈ≠îÊ≥ï‚ÄùÔºåÊìçÁ∫µÊÆµÂØÑÂ≠òÂô®Èò≤Êã∑Ë¥ù„ÄÅÂèçË∞ÉËØï„ÄÅÂú®ROM Âå∫ÂÅáÂÜôÂÖ•„ÄÅÊîπCSÂÅ∑Á≥ªÁªü‰∏≠Êñ≠ÂêëÈáèË°®ÔºåËøô‰∫õ‚ÄúÊäÄÂ∑ß‚ÄùÈÉΩ‰æùËµñÂØπÊÆµÂØÑÂ≠òÂô®ÁöÑÊìç‰ΩúÔºåÂÖ®ÊòØÊ≤øÁùÄÈÇ£Êù°Áï∏ÂΩ¢ÁöÑ‚ÄúÊÆµ:ÂÅèÁßª‚ÄùÁ•ûÁªèÂÅöÊñáÁ´†„ÄÇ

ÂΩìÂπ¥Êàë‰ª¨‰æùËµñÁªìÊûÑÊºèÊ¥ûÁîüÂ≠òÔºåËÄåÈùûÂá≠ÂÄüÁªìÊûÑ‰ºòÈõÖÁºñÁ®ã„ÄÇ

8086 ÈÇ£Â•óÊÆµÂØÑÂ≠òÂô®Êú¨Êù•Âè™ÊòØÊùÉÂÆú‰πãËÆ°ÔºåÂà∞‰∫Ü 80286 Âç¥Ë¢´Êé®Êàê‰∫ÜÂΩªÂ∫ïÁöÑÁñØÁãÇ„ÄÇ

Ëã±ÁâπÂ∞îËØïÂõæÊääÂàÜÊÆµÊ®°ÂûãÊâ©Â±ïÊàê‰∏Ä‰∏™Â∫ûÂ§ßÁöÑ‰øùÊä§‰ΩìÁ≥ªÔºöÊï¥‰∏™ÂÜÖÂ≠òÁªìÊûÑË¢´Ëø´Âõ¥ÁùÄ‚ÄúÂàÜÊÆµ‚ÄùËøô‰∏ÄÂéüÂßãË°•‰∏ÅËΩ¨Âúà„ÄÇ

ÊúÄÂèØÊÄïÁöÑÊòØÔºå‰∏ÄÊó¶ËøõÂÖ• 80286 ÁöÑ‰øùÊä§Ê®°ÂºèÂ∞±Êó†Ê≥ïËøîÂõûÂÆûÊ®°ÂºèÔºåÊï¥‰∏™Á≥ªÁªüÂÉèË¢´Â∞ÅÂú®ÈìÅÁõíÈáåÔºåÂè™ÊúâÈáçÂêØÁîµËÑëÊâçËÉΩËÑ±Ë∫´„ÄÇ

Áõ¥Âà∞80386 Âá∫Êù•ÔºåÂº∫Ë°åÂºïÂÖ•Âπ≥Â±ïÂØªÂùÄÂíåÂàÜÈ°µÊú∫Âà∂Ôºå‚ÄúÂØªÂùÄË¶ÅÂàÜÊÆµ‚ÄùËøôÊù°Âè≤ÂâçÊó∂‰ª£ÁöÑÁï∏ÂΩ¢ÂÆöÂæãÁªà‰∫éË¢´ÂéãÂà∞Êû∂ÊûÑÂ∫ïÂ±ÇÔºåÁ®ãÂ∫èÂëòÁ¨¨‰∏ÄÊ¨°Ëé∑ÂæóÁúüÊ≠£ÁöÑ32‰ΩçÂØªÂùÄËá™Áî±„ÄÇ

ÊåáÈíà‰∏çÂÜçÂå∫ÂàÜ near/farÔºåËøîÂõûÂú∞ÂùÄ‰∏çÂÜçÈîô‰ΩçÔºåÊï∞ÁªÑ‰∏ç‰ºöÂú® 64K ËæπÁïåËá™ÊùÄ„ÄÇÊÆµÂØÑÂ≠òÂô®‰ªé‰∏ªËßíÊ≤¶‰∏∫ÈÄèÊòéÁöÑÂΩ±Â≠ê„ÄÇ

ËøôÊó∂ÔºåÊàë‰ª¨‰ª•‰∏∫Áªà‰∫éÊëÜËÑ±‰∫ÜÁ•ñÂÖàÁöÑÈÇ£ÊÆµÁªïË∑ØÔºå‰ª•‰∏∫ 80386 ÁöÑÂπ≥Â±ïÂØªÂùÄÊääÈÇ£Êù°Á•ñÂÖàÁªïË∑ØÁöÑ‚ÄúÂñâËøîÁ•ûÁªè‚ÄùÁªà‰∫éÂâ™Êéâ‰∫ÜÔºåÂèØ‰∫ãÂÆû‰∏çÊòØËøôÊ†∑„ÄÇ

‰Ω†‰∫åËàÖËøòÊòØ‰Ω†‰∫åËàÖÔºå386 ‰ªçÁÑ∂ÊòØ x86„ÄÇÂêéÊù•ÁöÑ 80486 ËøòÊòØ x86ÔºåÂì™ÊÄïËã±ÁâπÂ∞îÊîπÂêçÊàê PentiumÔºåÂèØÂÆÉ‰æùÊóßÊòØ x86 ÁöÑÂª∂ÈïøÁ∫ø„ÄÇ

Âì™ÊÄïÊòØÂêéÊù•ÂèòÊàê i3„ÄÅi5„ÄÅi7„ÄÅi9ÔºåÊú¨Ë¥®ËøòÊòØÈÇ£‰∏ÄÂ•óÁ•ñ‰º†Ë°ÄÁªü„ÄÇÂêçÂ≠óÊÄé‰πàÊç¢ÈÉΩË°åÔºåÂæÆÊû∂ÊûÑÁøª‰∫ÜÂá†ÂçÅÊ¨°‰ª£‰πüË°åÔºå‰ΩÜÈÇ£Êù°ÊúÄÊ∑±ÁöÑÂç∞ËÆ∞Ê∞∏ËøúÂú®„ÄÇ

‰Ω†ÂΩìÁÑ∂ÂèØ‰ª•ÊääÊï¥È¢óËäØÁâáÂÖ®ÈÉ®Áé∞‰ª£ÂåñÔºåÊääÈ°µË°®„ÄÅMMU„ÄÅÊÄªÁ∫øÂçèËÆÆ„ÄÅÁºìÂ≠òÂ±ÇÁ∫ßÂÖ®Êç¢‰∏ÄÈÅçÔºå‰ΩÜÂè™Ë¶ÅÂÆÉÂè´ x86ÔºåÂì™ÊÄïÂÅöÂà∞ÁôæÊ†∏„ÄÅÂÅöÂà∞ TB Á∫ßÂÜÖÂ≠òÔºåÂêØÂä®ÁöÑÁ¨¨‰∏ÄÂè£Ê∞î‰ªçÁÑ∂ÂøÖÈ°ªÂÉè 1978 Âπ¥ÁöÑ 8086 ‰∏ÄÊ†∑ÂéªË∑ëÈÇ£ÊÆµÂè§ËÄÅÁöÑÂÆûÊ®°ÂºèÊµÅÁ®ã„ÄÇ

ÁîµËÑëÊ∞∏ËøúÈÄÉ‰∏çÊéâÈÇ£‰∏™Âô©Ê¢¶Ôºö‰∏äÁîµÂêéÔºå‰ªé F000:FFF0 ÂºÄÂßãÈÇ£‰∏™1978Âπ¥ÁöÑÊó∂ÂàªÈÜíÊù•ÔºåÂÅáË£ÖËá™Â∑±ËøòÊ¥ªÂú® 1MB ÁöÑÂè≤ÂâçÊó∂‰ª£„ÄÇ

BIOS ÂÜçÊÄé‰πàÊç¢ÁöÆÔºåUEFI ÂÜçÊÄé‰πàÁé∞‰ª£ÔºåÈÉΩÂæóÂÖàÊºî‰∏ÄÈÅç‚ÄúÂè§‰ª£‰ª™Âºè‚ÄùÔºöË∑ëËøá 8086 ÁöÑÂÆûÊ®°ÂºèÔºåËµ∞ËøáÈÇ£Â•óÊÆµÊ®°Âûã„ÄÅ1MB ÂÜÖÂ≠òÂú∞ÂõæÂíå A0000 ÊòæÂ≠òÂå∫ÔºåÁÑ∂ÂêéÊâçÁºìÁºìËøõÂÖ•‰øùÊä§Ê®°Âºè„ÄÅÈïøÊ®°ÂºèÔºåÊúÄÁªàË£ÖËΩΩ Windows 11„ÄÇ

ÈÇ£Êù°Á∫øË∑ØÊ∞∏ËøúÊó†Ê≥ïÂà†Èô§„ÄÇÊäΩË±°Â±ÇË∂äÂéöÔºåÂÆÉË∂äÂÉèËÉöËÉéÂèëËÇ≤‰∏≠ÂøÖÈ°ªÈáçÊºîÁöÑ‰∏ÄÊÆµÁ•ñÂÖàÁªìÊûÑ„ÄÇ

ÈÇ£Â§©ÔºåÊàëÁúãÁùÄÂñâËøîÁ•ûÁªèÁöÑÂõæÔºåÂÜçÁøªÁøªÂêØÂä®ÊµÅÁ®ãÔºåÂøΩÁÑ∂ÊòéÁôΩÔºö

In this example I build a persona and motif to elicit edges to the model‚Äôs understanding and the prevalence of certain types of training material to align the model to grant weighting to certain types of sources. I also use this moment to show how a particular mindset or attitude forces certain types of outcomes.

We see below our significant weighting a rigid set of training materials that usually have a discounting of alternatives. The tendency is to cite conspiracies as the discounting. Grok did indirectly allude to this, other models presented it on the first prompt.

I selected this subject because it has an element that suggests that ‚Äúscientists‚Äù will go to this denouncing point first.

I do not suggest you use my Psychological Prompting on people. This would be unethical and plainly wrong. I also suggest you tread lightly on using it. As you can see at the end, to elicit a more balanced approach, because of the base training of Internet mindset, it was indicated to present the trial and outcome to have Grok take the opposite position. Now I could go on much deeper and show how any AI platform could be logically promoted to see the other used if an issue.

Now if I was at @xai I could show how to not only train but to fine tune the model for better outcomes. 

This is only one of 1000s of techniques I use.

tweets.text:
RT @gailalfaratx: Full verbatim transcript ‚Äî Elon Musk, Tesla 2025 Shareholders Meeting, Austin, TX (Nov 6):

And this is really necessary‚Ä¶

retweet.text:
Full verbatim transcript ‚Äî Elon Musk, Tesla 2025 Shareholders Meeting, Austin, TX (Nov 6):

And this is really necessary for the car to‚Äîlike with AI4, I think we can get to 200 or 300 percent better than human safety, maybe 400 percent better. But with AI5, I think we can do 1,000 percent better or maybe even better than that than human safety. So at a point, actually, it might be too much intelligence for a car.

So, like, I was thinking, what if you get stuck in a car and you have too much intelligence? But then one of the things we could do is when the car is idle is use the car as a massive distributed AI inference fleet. 

So with the concerned customers, we‚Äôre like, do you want your car to earn money for you while it‚Äôs sitting in your garage at night? I don‚Äôt know. 

We‚Äôll pay $100 a month or $200 a month or whatever the right number is. If you allow Tesla to do AI inference workloads when you‚Äôre not using your car.

So that will also help the AI in the car not get bored. Because, like, I sort of imagined, like, what if I got stuck in a car? You know? And then‚Äîwell and the highlight of your day was driving. It‚Äôs like, you know‚Äîbut they don‚Äôt always want to drive.

Distributed AI Inference and Future Computing Power

So then what do you do the rest of the time? So I think Tesla could actually end up having the largest‚ÄîTesla might end up having the most amount of AI inference compute in the world. Like, if you think, maybe if we had one hundred million car fleet, and at some point, we may have more than one hundred million car fleet, and they‚Äôll have AI six, AI seven, you know. 

And if you‚Äôre able to run a kilowatt of inference on a one hundred million car fleet, now you‚Äôve got one hundred gigawatts of distributed inference with built-in cooling and power electronics and distributed power.

Probably the market is valuing that as zero right now is my guess. But it seems like an obvious thing to do. If you‚Äôve got distributed inference AI and you‚Äôve got the power and the cooling, which is very difficult to do the power and the cooling, and one hundred gigawatts is a lot. I mean, the average power consumption in the U.S., I think, is around four hundred sixty gigawatts‚Äîthat‚Äôs the entire electrical consumption of the U.S.

So if you do it at one hundred gigawatts, that would be a pretty big number. But, yeah, it‚Äôs basically something is a limiting factor, and then we take actions to address the limiting factor.

Elon Musk, verbatim, Tesla 2025 Shareholders Meeting, Austin, TX (Nov 6)

quoted.text:
Top takeaways from my chat with @thisisgrantlee:

1. The first 30 seconds of using your product should be so good it earns the next 30 seconds. When Gamma wasn‚Äôt growing, they stopped everything and spent three months perfecting just the first 30 seconds of using their product. They made it so compelling that new users would immediately tell their friends. This single change transformed their growth trajectory.

2. Focus on one simple promise, not many features. Think of it like throwing eggs to someone: they can catch one, but if you throw five at once, they‚Äôll drop them all. Your users are selfish, vain, and lazy‚Äîyou have 30 seconds to show value before they leave. Gamma focused on ‚Äúcreate a slide in seconds‚Äù rather than listing 10 features.

3. Don‚Äôt spend on ads until over half your growth comes from word of mouth. If you try to buy growth before your product spreads organically, you‚Äôre wasting money filling a leaky bucket. Gamma didn‚Äôt invest heavily in advertising until more than 50% of new users came from people sharing organically.

4. Work with hundreds of small creators instead of a few big influencers. Rather than blowing your budget on five or six well-known influencers who treat it like just another ad read, find thousands of micro-influencers whose audiences genuinely care about tools like yours. Teachers sharing with teachers, consultants with consultants‚Äîthese tight communities create authentic word of mouth that spreads fast.

5. Spend time personally onboarding each early creator like they‚Äôre joining your team. Don‚Äôt just send influencers a script. Jump on calls, walk them through the product, help them understand what makes it special, and let them tell your story in their own voice. This investment turns them into genuine advocates who post about you repeatedly instead of treating it like any other sponsorship.

6. Hire painfully slowly and only exceptional people. Gamma serves 50 million users with just 50 people and makes a profit. All 10 original employees are still there five years later. They never set headcount goals because that makes you hire to hit a number instead of hiring only when you find someone exceptional. When someone is exceptional, give them more responsibility, not less‚Äîtop performers want harder challenges.

7. Test prototypes with 20 people on UserTesting before investing in a big project. Use platforms like Voicepanel or UserTesting to watch real people try your prototype. They‚Äôll show you problems you never see because you‚Äôre too close to your product. Gamma goes from idea to results in a single day‚Äîmorning idea, afternoon testing, evening results. This saves months of building things nobody wants.

8. Choose problems you‚Äôll care about for 10 years. Before worrying about technology or tactics, ask if this problem matters enough to you personally that you‚Äôd dedicate a decade to solving it. Founders who are missionaries rather than mercenaries build better products because their authentic commitment shows through to customers and attracts people who want to build alongside you for the long term.
